facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 2537 of 1966 filed by special leave from judgment and decree dated September 22, 1966 of Andhra Pradesh High Court in Second Appeals Nos. 875 of 1961, 488 and 516 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 2537 of 1966. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and decree dated September 22, 1966 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Second Appeals Nos. 875 of 1961, 488 and 516 of 1962.

facts.text: Rice mill in Bhimiavaram, West Godavari District, formerly owned by appellant along with respondents 3, 4 and 5.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant facts are as follows. There is a rice mill in Bhimiavaram, West Godavari District, which was formerly owned by the appellant along with respondents 3, 4 and 5.

facts.text: Mill built on site of Ac. 1-75 by N. Raju who obtained lease from guardian of respondents 1 and 2 executed on 21st December 1941 expiring on 17th July 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The mill was built on a site with an area of Ac. 1-75 by one N. Raju who had obtained a lease thereof from the guardian of respondents 1 and 2. It was executed on 21st December 1941 and was to expire on 17th July 1956.

facts.text: Appellant and respondents 3, 4 and 5 were successors-in-interest of the leasehold rights.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and respondents 3, 4 and 5 were successors-in- interest of the said leasehold rights.

facts.text: Respondents 1 and 2 served notice of ejectment on lessees to quit site and deliver possession on expiry of lease.

anchor.surface_text: Respondents I and 2 served numberice of ejectment on the lessees to quit the site and deliver possession on the expiry of the said lease.

facts.text: Agreement arrived at on January 6, 1957 between appellant and respondent 5 for themselves and on behalf of 3 and 4, and respondents 1 and 2 for new lease for 30 years commencing January 1, 1957 at Rs. 5400 per annum payable every two months.

anchor.surface_text: According to the lessees there were negotiations for a new lease. Respondents I and 2 demanded enhanced rent and an agreement was ultimately arrived at on January 6, 1957 between the appellant and respondent No. 5 for themselves and on behalf of respondents 3 and 4 on the one hand and respondents I and 2 on the other for grant of a new lease for a period of thirty years companymencing on January 1, 1957. The rent was fixed at Rs. 5401- per annum payable every two months.

facts.text: Agreement included option to lessors to purchase rice mill at price fixed by President of Rice Mills Association; if not, lessees entitled to remove structures.

anchor.surface_text: There was an option given to the lessors to purchase the rice mill It a price to be fixed by the President of the Rice Mills Association but in case the said option was number exercised, the lessees were entitled to remove the structures of the mill.

facts.text: Agreement written on two stamp papers of Rs. 0-12-0 each, signed by appellant, 5th respondent, and respondent 1 on behalf of 2, delivered to respondent 1.

anchor.surface_text: The agreement was written on two stamp papers of Rs. 0-12-0 each and signed by the appellant and the 5th respondent on the one hand and respondent No. I on his own behalf and on behalf of respondent No. 2. The document was delivered to the respondent No. I after execution.

facts.text: Appellant effected considerable improvements to mill costing Rs. 30,000 and purchased shares of respondents 3 and 4.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants further case is that thereafter he effected companysiderable improvements to the mill companyting about Rs. 30,000, - and purchased the shares of respondents 3 and 4 in the said mill

facts.text: Respondent 5 sold his share to respondent 6 in September 1965.

anchor.surface_text: but respondent No. 5 who had originally joined the appellant in the suit for specific performance of the said agreement sold his share in or about September 1965 to respondent No. 6 herein.

facts.text: Respondents 1 and 2 instituted O.S. No. 81 of 1957 on March 12, 1957 in Court of District Munsif Bhimavaram against appellant, respondents 3,4,5 and others for possession after removing mill.

anchor.surface_text: On March 12, 1957 respondents I and 2 instituted a suit O.S. No. 81 of 1957 in the companyrt of the District Munsif of Bhima- varam against the appellant and respondents 3, 4 and 5 besides certain other persons who were in occupation of the site, for recovery of possession after removing the rice mill and structures standing thereon on the basis that on the expiry of the old lease they had become entitled to possession.

facts.text: Respondents 1 and 2 instituted S. No. 100 of 1957 on April 4, 1957 claiming damages Rs. 4,700 for 94 days from January 1, 1957 to April 4, 1957 at Rs. 50 per day.

anchor.surface_text: Respondents I and 2 instituted another suit S. No. 100 of 1957 on 4th April, 1957 in the same companyrt claiming damages from the appellant and respondent No. 5 for failure to deliver the site from 1st January, 1957 till date of delivery of possession. ... The total claim in this suit was companyputed at Rs. 4,700/- being the amount due for 94 days from 1st January, 1957 to 4th April, 1957 at the rate of Rs. 501per day.

facts.text: In plaint of S. No. 100/1957 paragraph 6 stated they would file separate suit for future mesne profits.

anchor.surface_text: In paragraph 6 of the plaint in this suit they expressly stated that they would file a separate suit to recover the future mesne profits.

facts.text: Appellant and respondent 5 instituted O.S. No. 92 of 1958 on April 5, 1958 against respondents 1 to 4 for specific performance of agreement to lease.

anchor.surface_text: On April 5, 1958 the, appellant and respondent No. 5 instituted O.S. No. 92 of 1958 against respondents 1 to 4 praying for specific performance of the agreement to lease mentioned above with a direction that the respondents 1 and 2 should execute the lease deed.

facts.text: In written statement in O.S. 92/1958, respondents 1 and 2 denied execution of agreement.

anchor.surface_text: By their written statement filed in O.S. No. 92 of 1958 respondents I and 2 denied the execution of the agreement to, lease

facts.text: Three suits tried together; respondents 1 and 2 did not produce original agreement; appellant led oral evidence to prove execution.

anchor.surface_text: The three suits were tried together. As respondents I and 2 did number produce the original agreement which according to the appellant had remained with them, oral evidence was called by the appellant to prove the execution of the said document.

facts.text: District Munsif held no right to lead oral evidence of agreement dated 6-1-1957 but recorded it; found not proved by P.Ws. 1 to 5 and 7.

anchor.surface_text: In his judgment the learned Munsif held The plaintiffs have numberright to lead any oral evidence in respect of the suit agreement to lease dated 6-1-1057. ... The plaintiffs on whom the burden lies have number proved by evidence of P.Ws., I to 5 and 7 which is interested and developed that the agreement to lease dated 6-1-1957 is true and valid.

facts.text: Munsif dismissed O.S. 92/1958, decreed O.S. 81/1957 for possession by July 9, 1960, decreed O.S. 100/1957 for Rs. 117-2-10.

anchor.surface_text: S. No. 92 of 1958 was therefore dismissed. O.S. No. 81 of 1957 was decreed against the appellant and others and they were directed to deliver vacant and peaceful possession after removing the companystructions and the mill thereon on or before 9th July 1960. Suit No. 100 of 1957 was decreed against the appellant and respondent No. 5 for Rs. 117-2-10.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge Narsapur on appeal set aside Munsif decrees, decreed specific performance directing execution of lease from January 1, 1957, accepted oral evidence, found objection to admissibility raised late due to suppression.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge, Narsapur who heard the appeals from the judgment and decrees of the learned Munsif set them aside. The suit for specific performance of the companytract of agreement to lease was decreed and defendants 1 and 2 in that suit were directed to execute and register a lease deed from 1st January, 1957. Ile accepted the oral evidence tendered on behalf of the plaintiffs in that suit and recorded that the objection regarding the admissibility of the oral evidence was raised only at the time of the argu- ments on the ground that the agreement was written On a stamp paper of Rs. 1-8-0 when it should have been written on a paper with a stamp of Rs. 60/-. According to the learned Subordinate Judge the defendants had suppressed the agreement to lease whereby the plaintiffs were deprived of the opportunity of making good the deficiency of the stamp.

facts.text: High Court held oral evidence inadmissible under ss. 35 and 36 Stamp Act, even though objection raised late.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in Second Appeal went elaborately into the question of the admissibility of the oral evidence regarding the agreement to lease and held that. although the objection was raised by defendants I and. 2 in the trial companyrt at the time of the final arguments and number before the oral evidence was received in regard to the admissibility of oral evidence, even then since section 36 is number attracted to such an objection, the oral evidence cannot be acted upon.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal is dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Respondents moved C.M.P. No. 87 of 1971 under Order 47 Rule 3 for direction to add relief for future mesne profits from date of suit.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents moved an application C.M.P. No. 87 of 1971 under Order 47 Rule 3of the Rules of this Court for a direction that a relief for future mesne profits from the date of the suit be added to the decree.

issues.text: whether reception of secondary evidence of a written agreement to rant a lease is barred by the provisions of ss. 35 and 36 of the Indian Stamp Act

anchor.surface_text: The main question in these three appeals is, whe- ther reception of secondary evidence of a written agreement to rant a lease is barred by the provisions of ss. 35 and 36 of the Indian Stamp Act.

issues.text: whether s. 36 of the Stamp Act applies to the admission without objection of secondary evidence (oral) of an insufficiently stamped document

anchor.surface_text: secondary evidence of the contents of the document could be led in terms of s. 65 a of the Evidence Act. The Evidence Act imposed no bar to the reception of oral evidence by way of secondary evidence to prove the terms of the agreement to lease which was in writing and duly executed.

issues.text: whether the proviso to s. 35 of the Stamp Act permits admission of secondary evidence upon payment of duty and penalty

anchor.surface_text: Proviso (a) is only applicable when the original instrument is actually before the court of law and the deficiency in stamp with penalty is paid by the party seeking to rely upon the document. Clearly secondary evidence either by way of oral evidence of the contents of the unstamped document or the copy of it tendered by s. 63 of the Indian Evidence Act would not fulfil the requirements of the proviso

holdings.text: The first limb of s. 35 clearly shuts out from evidence any instrument chargeable with duty unless it is duly stamped. The second limb of it which relates to acting upon the instrument will obviously shut out any secondary evidence of such instrument, for allowing such evidence to be let in when the original admittedly chargeable with duty was not stamped or insufficiently stamped would be tantamount to the document being acted upon by the person having by law or authority to receive evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The first limb of s. 35 clearly shuts out from evidence any instrument chargeable with duty unless it is duly stamped. The second limb of it which relates to acting upon the instrument will obviously shut out any secondary evidence of such instrument, for allowing such evidence to be let in when the original

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 35 bars admission and acting upon unstamped instruments; secondary evidence equates to acting on the original unstamped document.

holdings.text: Proviso (a) is only applicable when the original instrument is actually before the court of law and the deficiency in stamp with penalty is paid by the party seeking to rely upon the document. Clearly secondary evidence either by way of oral evidence of the contents of the unstamped document or the copy of it tendered by s. 63 of the Indian Evidence Act would not fulfil the requirements of the proviso.

anchor.surface_text: Proviso (a) is only applicable when the original instrument is actually before the court of law and the deficiency in stamp with penalty is paid by the party seeking to rely upon the document. Clearly secondary evidence either by way of oral evidence of the contents of the unstamped document or

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso requires physical presence of original for payment of duty and penalty; secondary evidence cannot satisfy this condition.

holdings.text: The words an instrument in s. 36 must have the same meaning as that in S. 35. [...] Section 36 only relented from the strict provisions of S. 35 in cases where the original instrument was admitted in evidence without objection at the initial stage [...] But this in no way extends the applicability of s. 36 to secondary evidence adduced or sought to be adduced.

anchor.surface_text: The words an instrument in s. 36 must have the same meaning as that in S. 35. The legislature only relented from the strict provisions of S. 35 in cases where the original instrument was admitted in evidence without objection at the initial stage of a suit or proceeding.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Instrument' in s.36 refers to original as in s.35; no application to secondary evidence even if admitted without objection.

holdings.text: As the first court of appeal recorded the finding that it was the defendants who were responsible for suppression of the original agreement to lease, a finding which was accepted by the High Court, it must be held that no objection to the reception of secondary evidence by way of oral evidence can be raised under the provisions of the Indian Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: As the first court of appeal recorded the finding that it was the defendants who were responsible for suppression of the original agreement to lease, a finding which was accepted by the High Court, it must be held that no objection to the reception of secondary evidence by way of oral

holdings.reasoning_summary: Suppression of original by opponent permits secondary evidence under Evidence Act ss.65,91.

holdings.text: The Indian Evidence Act however does not purport to deal with the admissibility of documents in evidence which require to be stamped under the provisions of the Indian Stamp Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Indian Evidence Act however does not purport to deal with the admissibility of documents in evidence which require to be stamped under the provisions of the Indian Stamp Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence Act governs general admissibility of secondary evidence, but Stamp Act imposes additional fiscal bar on unstamped documents.

holdings.text: In the result the appeal is dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal is dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appeal lacks merit based on above legal conclusions upholding High Court judgment.

precedents.citation: Raja of Bobbili Imuganti China Sitaramaswami Garu 1 ... 1 23 Madras 49

anchor.surface_text: One of the earliest decisions is the judgment of the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council in Raja of Bobbili Imuganti China Sitaramaswami Garu 1 . In this case, a suit was brought by the Raja of Bobbili to obtain the proprietary possession of an estate once belonging to the family.

precedents.case_name: Raja of Bobbili v. Imuganti China Sitaramaswami Garu
precedents.cited_proposition: Secondary evidence (copy or oral) of an insufficiently stamped original document cannot be admitted in evidence upon payment of penalty under the Stamp Act; only the original can be validated.
precedents.cited_holding: The clauses deal exclusively with original documents; secondary evidence cannot be subjected to penalty for admissibility.

precedents.citation: The State of Bihar v. Karam Chand Thapar Bros Ltd. 1 ... 1 1962 1 S.C.R. 827

anchor.surface_text: More than sixty years after the above decision this Court observed that the law laid down there was well-settled and that a copy of an instrument could not be validated The State of Bihar v. Karam Chand Thapar Bros Ltd. 1

precedents.case_name: State of Bihar v. Karam Chand Thapar Bros Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: Law that copy of instrument cannot be validated under Stamp Act is well-settled.

precedents.citation: Thaji Beebi v. Tirumalappa Pillai 1 ... 1 30 Madras 336 at 337

anchor.surface_text: in Thaji Beebis case supra the plaintiff sued upon a cadjan mortgage which was said to be, in possession of the first defendant whose ancestors were alleged to have created the mortgage in favour of the plaintiffs ancestors. The first defendant denied tile existence of any such deed.

precedents.cited_proposition: Unstamped instrument cannot be given effect through secondary evidence or connection to possession.
precedents.cited_holding: To hold otherwise would be contrary to s.35 of Stamp Act.

anchor.surface_text: In Chidambaram v. Meyyappan 1 the plaintiffs produced an unstamped document as the basis of their claim. Before the trial commenced a mob invaded the court and set fire to it with the result that records of many cases including the record of the above case were destroyed.

precedents.cited_proposition: Cause of non-production (even destruction) does not allow secondary evidence of unstamped document.

precedents.citation: Maung Po Htoo and three v. Ma Ma Gyi and one 3 ... 3 I.L.R. 4 Rangoon 363

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sen relied strongly on certain observations in a judgment of the Rangoon High Court in Maung Po Htoo and three v. Ma Ma Gyi and one 3 . This arose out of a suit for administration of the estate of one Daw Thet San and for a declaration that a deed of gift executed by him was void.

precedents.case_name: Maung Po Htoo v. Ma Ma Gyi
precedents.cited_proposition: Secondary evidence of insufficiently stamped document can be admitted under s.35 read with Evidence Act.

precedents.citation: Satyavati v. Pallayya 1 ... A.I.R. 1937 Madras 431 at 432

anchor.surface_text: For the same reason we must hold that the dictum in Satyavati v. Pallayya 1 that S. 35 will also apply when secondary evidence of an instrument not duly stamped had been wrongly admitted. is not good. law.

precedents.cited_proposition: S.35 applies to wrongly admitted secondary evidence of unstamped instrument.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant also relied on the decision in Ponnuswami v. Kailasam 1 . In this case a suit as filed for recovery of the loans which were evidenced as two documents described as hand letters which were admittedly unstamped.

precedents.cited_proposition: Admission of execution allows decree without proving unstamped documents.

precedents.citation: Alimana Sahiba v. Subbarayudu 2 ... A.I.R. 1932 Madras 693

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge of the Madras High Court relied on an earlier decision of that court in Alimana Sahiba v. Subbarayudu 2 wherein a suit had been filed on a promissory note which bore a stamp paper but the same was not cancelled.

precedents.cited_proposition: Facts admitted need not be proved even if document inadmissible; s.36 prevents reopening.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal is dismissed with costs.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed; oral secondary evidence of insufficiently stamped agreement to lease held inadmissible under Indian Stamp Act ss. 35 and 36
